quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Canva is bigger than Figma and Miro and Webflow combined. You guys are generating $2.3 billion in ARR and you're profitable. You're also growing 60% year over year and it's accelerating.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete scale and growth metrics that set a high-performance benchmark and anchor the discussion in real numbers.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I run everyone through the culture of Canva. One of those sections is on giving away your Lego, finding joy in the other things of building a team, passing on your experience, helping other people do great writing or great product building or great product building or great engineering.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for leadership: shifting from individual ownership to enabling others as the organization scales.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We don't really have managers, but everyone at Canva has a coach. They're constantly working with you to look at your skills, but also when it might be time to move on to the next level.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive org design approach that replaces traditional management with continuous coaching and explicit growth planning.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I have seen product managers at other companies who are very independent of teams and that seems very weird to me. For us, product managers are really connected.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A clear stance on PM operating model: tight team integration over independent, detached product leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I still think I'm constantly growing, I'm constantly learning stuff. I don't feel like I've achieved a ceiling or being a massive smash hit.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A practitioner mindset for sustained performance: treat success as ongoing learning rather than an endpoint.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising scare and commitment to profitability
quotes.text: And about two days before they were due to sign and get all the money into our account, they came back and said, "Look, business is going great, but essentially we think we can get a better deal, so we're going to cut your valuation by 50%."
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of last-minute investor leverage that highlights why founders should plan for fundraising volatility.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising scare and commitment to profitability
quotes.text: We eventually came out of it better. We actually got better terms on the deal that we came up with.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Shows that a fundraising crisis can be turned into improved outcomes by quickly re-running the process and finding a better lead.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising scare and commitment to profitability
quotes.text: That investor has fallen to the wayside now and it was a real learning moment for us in terms of how to approach fundraising and also how to be totally independent, and that's one of the reasons why we've focused on profitability for so long now.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Connects a specific fundraising failure to a durable operating principle: prioritize independence via profitability.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising scare and commitment to profitability
quotes.text: we never want to be put in the situation where we have to go to someone for money to ensure the survival of the business, and being profitable means that we never have to do that.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for practitioners: profitability reduces existential dependency on external capital and preserves negotiating power.

quotes.topic_title: Fundraising scare and commitment to profitability
quotes.text: We can always do it on our own terms and in our own time.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the strategic benefit of profitability: control over timing and terms of major decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a predictable inflection point for SaaS teams to plan enterprise readiness (auth/provisioning) before it becomes urgent.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes a practical build-vs-buy criterion: choose tools that minimize cognitive load and time-to-ship.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a drop-in replacement for Auth0 and supports up to one million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark (free tier scale + replacement claim) useful for evaluating switching costs and early-stage economics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Something that I've heard from one of your investors actually will not be named is that at your board meetings, you have one slide on the financials of the business and then the rest of the deck is product updates, the roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Offers a counterintuitive board-meeting operating model that prioritizes product/roadmap over financial deep-dives at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I think this is very rare, especially for companies at your stage that become really focused on financials in the business from the CFO perspective and a lot of founders lose sight of the product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Calls out a common failure mode—over-indexing on finance—reinforcing product focus as a strategic advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Product obsession and board meeting focus
quotes.text: We approach a board meeting just like we do anything, we craft the experience about how we think it should be and how we think it's going to be useful.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A reusable operating principle: intentionally design key meetings like product experiences to maximize usefulness and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Product obsession and board meeting focus
quotes.text: We've always been an incredibly product-led company. We always think first and foremost about the product.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A clear prioritization heuristic for decision-making that practitioners can adopt to keep teams anchored on product value.

quotes.topic_title: Product obsession and board meeting focus
quotes.text: In terms of board meetings, I think it's been very helpful that our financials and our growth have been amazing for so many years that we don't need to focus on it and we can just have that one slide with the graph going up and to the right.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of reducing financial reporting overhead when performance is strong, freeing time for product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Product obsession and board meeting focus
quotes.text: We've also attracted investors who believe in us and who understand that us driving product and getting as much product value out to our customers is probably the most important thing we can be doing.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Highlights investor alignment as a lever to protect product-first execution and avoid finance-first board dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Product obsession and board meeting focus
quotes.text: Obviously, financials are important and you can do a bunch of lever pulling and thinking about margins and all that kind of stuff, but product is at the end of the day the most important thing to Canva and the thing that's going to help us stand out and continue to have success.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A contrarian emphasis that differentiation and long-term success are driven primarily by product, not financial optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Homegrown leadership and culture fit
quotes.text: I think you can probably bring in the world's best person at X, Y, and Z, but if they're not fitting into your team and understanding your culture and have the same passion and vision that you do, they're not going to succeed.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A hiring principle that prioritizes culture and alignment over “best-in-class” credentials to protect execution speed.

quotes.topic_title: Homegrown leadership and culture fit
quotes.text: They mightn't be the number one person in the world for that particular thing, but they get more done than the number one person could because they've built that trust and that safety with their team.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Counterintuitive performance model: team trust and psychological safety can outperform raw individual talent.

quotes.topic_title: Homegrown leadership and culture fit
quotes.text: We have brought in leaders, and they've exited the company after a few months just because there wasn't that fit and they didn't manage to figure out or understand what Canva was and how to work within this big ecosystem.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of how even senior hires can fail quickly when they don’t adapt to the company’s operating system.

quotes.topic_title: Homegrown leadership and culture fit
quotes.text: We need to be able to see it. We need mock-ups. We need prototypes. You need to get that idea out of your head and present it to someone in a visual form that helps you talk about and communicate about it.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: An actionable communication methodology: make ideas visual early to align teams and improve decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Homegrown leadership and culture fit
quotes.text: So you really need to work together and I think the advice that I can give to people coming to Canva is just listen for a couple of months, figure out what is really working at Canva and why it works before you try and change it.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Practical onboarding guidance for new leaders: observe and learn the local system before importing external playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Giving away your Legos to scale
quotes.text: As a startup, you just have to be changing and we want people who are flexible, you can bring new ideas, you can go to that next level.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Defines the core scaling mindset Canva looks for: continuous change and leveling up rather than perfecting a static role.

quotes.topic_title: Giving away your Legos to scale
quotes.text: If you're the first email copywriter at Canva, you can get away from writing all the emails for the first year maybe, but when you're writing emails for 100 million people in 190 different countries, in 100 different languages, all at different stages of their journey through using Canva from beginners to intermediates to experts, that just massively multiplies the complexity of the job that you have to do.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete scaling example showing how scope explodes with growth, forcing a shift from doing work to designing systems.

quotes.topic_title: Giving away your Legos to scale
quotes.text: So you need to think about who you're going to bring in to help you, what systems you're going to introduce, what are the processes needed to get 100 different languages translated every time you send out an email and that requires you to hand off that stuff.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on scaling: hire, systematize, and build repeatable processes—then deliberately delegate.

quotes.topic_title: Giving away your Legos to scale
quotes.text: But finding joy in the other things of building a team, passing on your experience, helping other people do great writing or great product building or great engineering is really what giving away your Lego is about.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Captures the “give away your Lego” mental model: shifting identity from individual craft to enabling others’ excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Giving away your Legos to scale
quotes.text: Probably the deeper thing I think is giving people opportunity so you can talk about growth than just say, "Please grow." That's not going to be terribly effective, but giving them the opportunity and the support to do so is super important.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive culture lesson: growth isn’t a slogan—leaders must create real opportunities and support structures.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching model instead of traditional managers
quotes.text: We don't really have managers. So your coach is the person who thinks about you in a specialty sense.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A clear, countertraditional framing of replacing people management with specialty-based coaching.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching model instead of traditional managers
quotes.text: They know the trajectory that you could possibly grow into. They know the structures that are around Canva that you could slot into when you want to go to the next level.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Describes a practical coaching model focused on mapping skills to internal opportunities and progression paths.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching model instead of traditional managers
quotes.text: They're people in the company. So we've got probably close to 800 or 1,000 coaches now at Canva.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing the scale of Canva’s internal coaching network rather than relying on external professionals.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching model instead of traditional managers
quotes.text: what we're focused on is enabling the broader circle of coaches, so those 800 people to understand what it is to be a coach and have the skills of coaching.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Actionable emphasis on building coaching capability broadly across the org, not concentrating it in a few roles.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching model instead of traditional managers
quotes.text: So your coach feeds into that, but we also do 360 feedback from all the people that you work with and we do that on regular cycles.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A methodology for performance evaluation that combines coach input with systematic 360 feedback.

quotes.topic_title: How Canva defines product management
quotes.text: Google's a fantastically engineering-driven culture and the way that they think about product management is mostly in the technical sense of like, "Here's a piece of technology, what can that technology do, how do we scale it?" At Canva, we focus a lot on experience and as I said before, it's a very visual experience, so we require a different product management process, but also a different product management mindset.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Highlights how PM practice should be tailored to company culture and product nature (tech-first vs experience-first), not copied from famous playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: How Canva defines product management
quotes.text: I think we probably did that more from the ground up than a lot of other startups just because Mel and Cliff were a lot less, I think, inculcated into how product management has done other places.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Suggests a first-principles approach to PM design can be an advantage when founders aren’t constrained by inherited norms.

quotes.topic_title: How Canva defines product management
quotes.text: we didn't want to have the term product manager for a long, long time. It wasn't until about year '06 or '07 where we actually had product managers, we decided to cave just because it was easier to explain to people.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example that titles can be a communication tool rather than a prerequisite for doing the work of product management.

quotes.topic_title: How Canva defines product management
quotes.text: For us, product managers are really connectives. They connect the team, ideas, data, a whole bunch of different things, and it's very messy. There's no exact recipe for how to do it, but connecting these disparate areas and moving the team and the technology and our customers to a new place, a new vision is essentially what product managers do
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Defines a memorable PM mental model—PMs as “connectives” whose core job is alignment and movement toward a vision amid ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: How Canva defines product management
quotes.text: it's going to involve compromise, it's going to involve changes in the feature scope, it's going to involve timelines of like, "Okay, we can't ship it in May, it's going to have to be July. Let's figure out what we can do with marketing to make that work."
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Concrete, actionable depiction of PM value as cross-functional tradeoff management (scope, time, and go-to-market coordination).

quotes.topic_title: Co-founding dynamics with a married couple
quotes.text: I think they've done a really good job of evolving those ideas overnight through the conversations they have and over dinner and walking, but then bringing that back the next day and being transparent about that and that's super important.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Highlights the key operating principle for couple co-founders: rapid offline iteration is fine as long as it’s transparently re-shared with the team.

quotes.topic_title: Co-founding dynamics with a married couple
quotes.text: There are definitely moments where I have missed out on a memo and stuff has rapidly proceeded, and I think I've just gotten used to that and gotten used to catching up really quickly, having a word with them on the side to clarify what the motivation is here and just constantly maintaining that alignment.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Practical tactic for avoiding information gaps: proactively “catch up,” clarify motivations, and continuously re-align when decisions move fast.

quotes.topic_title: Co-founding dynamics with a married couple
quotes.text: There's always these moments where you need to re-communicate things and relay the land of it.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that alignment isn’t one-and-done; it requires periodic re-communication to reset shared understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Co-founding dynamics with a married couple
quotes.text: There's moments where there's small alignments, there's more tectonic stuff that happens over months or years, and you need to realign at some stage.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Introduces a useful framework for team dynamics: expect both minor drift and major “tectonic” shifts, and plan to realign accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When it comes to ensuring your company has top-notch security practices, things get complicated fast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical reality that security/compliance complexity escalates quickly, motivating early investment in scalable processes/tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now, you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers, and automate compliance for SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA, and more with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable framing of a unified approach—risk + customer trust + compliance automation—across multiple standards in one system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete productivity claim practitioners can apply immediately by using AI to reduce time spent on repetitive security questionnaires.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I know that it took you guys a year of building before you launched it, so it took you a year to build the MVP essentially.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific example that challenges the common “ship MVP ASAP” norm by noting a successful case where MVP took a year.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And I know you have some strong opinions on how long to wait, how MVPs are often way too early.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Sets up a counterintuitive product-development stance: delaying launch can be beneficial when MVPs are prematurely released.

quotes.topic_title: MVP timing: why Canva waited a year
quotes.text: I think, for us, the product is the experience and giving people a great experience is an intrinsic part of the product.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Reframes MVP thinking: for experience-driven products, “experience quality” is a core feature, not polish.

quotes.topic_title: MVP timing: why Canva waited a year
quotes.text: People just telling someone else to jump on this amazing product, I don't think we would've had that if we just put our pretty crappy product that people didn't have joy in using.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Explains why delaying launch can be rational when word-of-mouth is the primary growth engine.

quotes.topic_title: MVP timing: why Canva waited a year
quotes.text: you have to launch something that you're not completely happy with, all the rough edges, but you're releasing it knowing that the rough edges are going to be outweighed by the joyful experience.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Provides a practical launch bar: ship when delight outweighs rough edges, not when it’s perfect.

quotes.topic_title: MVP timing: why Canva waited a year
quotes.text: I often hear people are like, "I want to do a tech startup. What is the best area I should focus on to build a product in?" And to me, that is totally the wrong way to go about building a company that you're going to spend the next 10, 20 years in because if you're in an area that you are particularly passionate about but you see the opportunity to make a bit of money or have some external measure of success, that is a terrible way to go about being a founder because you're going to hit these rock bottom dark places and if the passion isn't driving you through that, you're going to have an incredibly hard time getting to the next step.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Counterintuitive founder guidance: optimize for passion and endurance through “dark places,” not market “best areas.”

quotes.topic_title: MVP timing: why Canva waited a year
quotes.text: It needs to light up their eyes. They need to be like, "How do I sign up for this thing tomorrow? How do I get it? How do I pay for it?" And they need to want to talk to other people about it because in the early days of your startup, you don't have marketing dollars, you don't have channels which you can go to immediately get access to a million people.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Defines an actionable MVP success criterion tied to early-stage distribution constraints: excitement that drives sharing and willingness to pay.

quotes.topic_title: Finding the first ICP: social media managers
quotes.text: But through the user testing that we did, through the levels of excitement that we saw from different people, social media managers really came to the fore at that time.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A practical ICP-finding method: run user tests and follow the segment showing the highest excitement signal.

quotes.topic_title: Finding the first ICP: social media managers
quotes.text: We didn't ship a presentation product or a T-shirt builder in our very first version. We shipped a thing that could make square landscape and portrait graphics and blog post graphics, and that got a particular segment of society excited.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of narrowing initial scope to match what a small team can deliver for a specific early adopter segment.

quotes.topic_title: Finding the first ICP: social media managers
quotes.text: It was just incredibly emotive language, like sheer joy.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for product/segment fit: look for emotional, high-intensity user reactions rather than mild approval.

quotes.topic_title: Finding the first ICP: social media managers
quotes.text: And when user tested the onboarding of Canva a ton, actually usertesting.com had just launched them, which really unlocked us because we didn't have to do these big formal labs or anything like that. We could just go online and get results in the space of half an hour.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: An actionable research process: rapid, lightweight onboarding tests can replace slow formal labs and speed iteration dramatically.

quotes.topic_title: Finding the first ICP: social media managers
quotes.text: And in the first minute of Canva with the right onboarding, it just unlocked the whole realm of productivity and impact that they didn't have before and that's why they got super excited.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A specific onboarding goal: demonstrate value fast enough (within the first minute) to unlock activation for the core ICP.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding lessons: defeating the blank page
quotes.text: So what we really focused on was just taking that first step and then the next step and then the next step. And before they knew it, they built a design.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A simple onboarding methodology: sequence tiny actions to quickly create a meaningful outcome and overcome “blank page” paralysis.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding lessons: defeating the blank page
quotes.text: So the first one was click on this search box and search for a monkey. It literally said that.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of using a surprising, low-effort first task to hook users and get them moving immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding lessons: defeating the blank page
quotes.text: The words that we literally got out of years at testing were, I didn't know I could be a designer.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Shows the target emotional outcome of onboarding: building user confidence and identity shift through early wins.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding lessons: defeating the blank page
quotes.text: It is lowering the barriers to entry and also increasing the amount of delight, and I think those two things are what you should be aiming for with your onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A memorable two-variable model for onboarding optimization: reduce effort while increasing delight.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding lessons: defeating the blank page
quotes.text: So with every launch that we do now, we think about how to teach people about that feature and how to get them really involved in it.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A repeatable practice: treat feature launches as onboarding moments with built-in education and hands-on activation.

quotes.topic_title: SEO template growth engine and end-to-end flow
quotes.text: He set up a whole team of people who looked at people's motivations and the top jobs to be done that Canva could service. He then mapped that through the entire experience of going into Google, typing a search query, getting that search query, seeing that it was a great result, firstly getting to the top result, but then also the experience after they landed on Canva.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A practical framework for operationalizing SEO by starting with jobs-to-be-done and mapping them end-to-end from search intent to on-site experience.

quotes.topic_title: SEO template growth engine and end-to-end flow
quotes.text: So if they searched for want to make a Halloween poster, the top Google result would be Canva. They'd click on it, they'd land on the Halloween poster landing page. It would tell them how they were going to do, it show you how the product was going to do that, have a button there that immediately took them into a Halloween poster template, went through a fantastic onboarding of customizing that poster really simply, and then they would hit done, download the image, and they had a fantastic experience and he thought through that whole end-to-end flow from first landing on Google and typing into the search box through to that magic moment where they're like, "Canva just helped me do something amazing and I want to do it again."
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example of designing the full SEO-to-activation funnel, including landing page, template handoff, onboarding, and the “magic moment.”

quotes.topic_title: SEO template growth engine and end-to-end flow
quotes.text: Yeah. Again, it's like product led truly means product led because you can't just SEO the hell out of something that is a terrible experience.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that SEO scale depends on the product delivering on the promise, not just ranking tactics.

quotes.topic_title: SEO template growth engine and end-to-end flow
quotes.text: So tying that experience at the end of the SEO journey is just as important as the technicalities of SEO itself, and Andre really harnessed the whole spectrum of that to produce the end experience, which ultimately ended up with an active user having a delightful experience.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to treat post-click product experience as a first-class part of SEO strategy, not an afterthought.

quotes.topic_title: SEO template growth engine and end-to-end flow
quotes.text: I think as an Australian company, we're fortunate in that Australia isn't a great market to focus on. We've got 25 million people here. It's okay, but it's not sizeable. It's not going to make you a huge success.
quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth lesson (with a specific data point) that forced early internationalization strategy.
